block.p: INTERNATIONAL

Former Soviet Jews Find Uneasy Home in Germany Germany's Jewish population has surpassed 100,000 for the first time since Hitler dispersed and destroyed a prewar community of over 500,000 Jews. At least 5,000 Jews pour in a year, supported by annual state payments, even as German impatience with Holocaust-induced obligations is rising.

Mexico Leader Courts Rivals Vicente Fox, Mexico's president-elect, has turned traditional post-election hand-kissing rituals upside down, using the weeks since his victory to visit his vanquished rivals to apologize for his slashing attacks on them during the campaign.

U.N. Patrols Lebanon Border United Nations peacekeepers finally began deploying in force along Lebanon's border with Israel, after weeks of haggling over just where the border was and 22 years after their presence was first authorized.

Bosnian Banker Arrested A former Bosnian interior minister and part-owner of a bank in which the United States government lost $900,000 was arrested, the police said. The charges were related to organized crime, a United Nations spokesman said, declining to give further details.
(AP)

3 Aid Workers Missing Three Red Cross aid workers -- a Frenchwoman, her Italian colleague and their Georgian driver -- were missing in Georgia near the border with the breakaway Russian republic of Chechnya.
(AP)
NATIONAL

Clinton Vetoes Tax Break For Couples, as Promised President Clinton has vetoed a tax break for married couples, saying it is too costly. The veto, which Mr. Clinton had long threatened, sets the stage for a renewed fight with Republicans over tax policy.
G.O.P. Courts Local Media The Republican Party worked hard to keep its convention in the news in local markets, especially in crucial states like Florida, Ohio, Illinois, Pennsylvania and Michigan.
Gov. George W. Bush signed a proclamation declaring June 10 to be Jesus Day in Texas; he has now come under criticism from groups who say the measure shows insensitivity.
Many of Vice President Al Gore's close friends are unhappy with news coverage that portrays him as stiff or cynical.
Vice President Al Gore will begin a campaign tour on Tuesday, when he plans to appear for the first time with his running mate.

Phone Strike Deadline Passes The contracts for more than 86,000 telephone workers expired after Verizon Communications was unable to reach an agreement with its unions. Still, both sides continued to talk.

Child Labor on Farms About 150,000 children 16 years or younger, most of them migrants, work long days on farms picking fruit and vegetables under harsh conditions. Democrats in Congress are planning legislation to make it harder to hire them.
NEW YORK/REGION

Uneven Medical Treatment Affects Outcome of Rape Trials The level of competence in administering forensic exams at New York City hospitals for victims of sex crimes varies widely. This uneven quality of care, experts say, can mean an uneven quality of evidence with which to prosecute some of society's most malevolent criminals.
Arrest in Strangulation Killings The police charged Vincent Johnson, 31, with the killings of four women in Brooklyn.

Center of West Nile Virus Staten Island is now the focal point of the West Nile virus, according to the borough president, although many residents are not taking extraordinary precautions to avoid becoming infected.
